moves.8... Qe4+ 9. Qe3: Oops, this leaves the bishop undefended.  Black should play QxBc4.
moves.10... Qxe3+ 11. dxe3 Be6: White splits black's pawns by trading bishops.  Split pawns are harder for black to defend.
moves.12. b3 Nc6 13. Nf3 a6 14. O-O Bd6 15. Nd: Black has more power here (bishop plus knight), this sacrifices the knight for nought.
moves.15... Bxd5 16. a4 Bxf3: Black breaks white's castle, doubling pawns.
moves.17. gxf3 Rab8: Rad8 probably would likely have been better.  Rook on center file exerts greater control over the battlefield.
moves.18. f4 Ne7 19. h4 Nh5 20. e4: Withdrawing cover for Pf4 gives black this pawn.  White's black bishop cannot compete against black's knight and bishop.
moves.20... Ng6: Black would have been better off taking the pawn.  The other pawn, h4, is easy pickings.
moves.22. f4 Nd7: All even trades now favor black, given the knight advantage.  NxBc4 also splits white pawns.
moves.23. f6: Two knights chomp this bit.  But it is a clever ruse, allowing whit to pawn fork black.  Still, NdxPf6 works, because bc5+ let's black escape the fork.
moves.25. Bd3 Ng3: Rf3 keeps pressure on the knight.  White will make back a bishop or knight.
moves.28... Rfd8: Yikes!  PxPc7 forks black's rooks!  Blunder!
moves.29. dxc7 Nf8 30. cxd8=Q: The other rook robs black's control over the center.
moves.34... Nf4: Keep it on the D file.
moves.35. Re3: :(. Nc2 forks the rooks.  But black must push the white bishop first.
moves.39. Kf2: BxNe2 was SUCH a better move.
moves.41. Bxf6 Nxb3 42. Bxc3 Nc5: While a bishop pawn combo is usually good, Ne4+ gives black another bishop.
